MUS 1.title: Classical Music Live
MUS 1.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Ticketsand transportation are provided free of charge. Primarily for non-Music majors. For full course information, please go to: www.music.ucsb.
MUS 1.description: Students meet for a one-hour pre-concert lecture given by Music Department faculty, and then attend world-class symphony concerts sponsored by Santa Barbara's Community Arts Music Association.

MUS 3A.title: Introduction to Music Studies
MUS 3A.comments: Quarters usually offered: Fall. Designed for Music Majors and Minors. Open to Music Majors, or by permission of instructor. Music minors and non-majors should contact instructor by email for permission to enroll.
MUS 3A.description: Introduces students to ways of studying music as a cultural practice situated in society. Methods are drawn from musicology, ethnomusicology, history, anthropology, and sociology. Students will be taught to think critically about music as a universal human expression.

MUS 3B.title: Writing about Music
MUS 3B.prereq_description: Music 3A with a minimum grade of C-, or consent of instructor.
MUS 3B.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Winter. Designed for Music Majors and Minors. Open to students who have taken Music 3A, or by permission of instructor. Contact instructor by email for permission to enroll.
Repeat Comments: Mus 3B is a legal repeat of Mus 12.
MUS 3B.description: Acquaints students with different approaches to writing and speaking about music of many traditions. The works of performers, critics, music theorists, ethnographers, musicologists, and historians will all be represented in the selection of assigned readings.

MUS 3C.title: Structures of Music
MUS 3C.prereq_description: Music 3B with a minimum grade of C-, or consent of instructor.
MUS 3C.comments: Quarters usually offered: Spring. Designed for Music Majors and Minors. Open to students who have taken Music 3B, or by permission of instructor. Contact instructor by email for permission to enroll.
MUS 3C.description: Looking at a variety of music traditions from different parts of the world, the class will survey varying approaches to issues of compositional structure, rhythm, intonation, scales, etc. The class will have listening and practical components.

MUS 4A.title: Musicianship
MUS 4A.prereq_description: Placement exam. A grade of at least C- is required in each course of the Music 4 series. Must be taken consecutively, and concurrently with the Music 5 series.
MUS 4A.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
MUS 4A.description: A practical course in sight singing, aural analysis, and rhythmic studies.

MUS 4B.title: Musicianship
MUS 4B.prereq_description: Placement Exam. A grade of at least C- is required in each course of the Music 4 series. Must be taken consecutively, and concurrently with the Music 5 series.
MUS 4B.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
MUS 4B.description: A practical course in sight singing, aural analysis, and rhythmic studies.

MUS 4C.title: Musicianship
MUS 4C.prereq_description: Placement Exam. A grade of at least C- is required in each course of the
MUS 4C.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
MUS 4C.description: A practical course in sight singing, aural analysis, and rhythmic studies.

MUS 4D.title: Musicianship
MUS 4D.prereq_description: Placement Exam. A grade of at least C- is required in each course of the
MUS 4D.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
MUS 4D.description: A practical course in sight singing, aural analysis, and rhythmic studies.

MUS 4E.title: Musicianship
MUS 4E.prereq_description: Placement Exam. A grade of at least C- is required in each course of the
MUS 4E.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
MUS 4E.description: A practical course in sight singing, aural analysis, and rhythmic studies.

MUS 4F.title: Musicianship
MUS 4F.prereq_description: Placement Exam. A grade of at least C- is required in each course of the
MUS 4F.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
MUS 4F.description: A practical course in sight singing, aural analysis, and rhythmic studies.

MUS 5A.title: Theory of Western Art Music: Fundamentals
MUS 5A.description: Theory basics, including rhythm and meter, pitch, intervals, scales, keys, triads, seventh chords, and essentials of harmonic progression.

MUS 5B.title: Theory of Western Art Music: Harmonic Practices and Analysis I
MUS 5B.prereq_description: Placement exam. A grade of at least C- is required in each course of the
MUS 5B.description: Textural deployments of harmony, tonic and dominant on the small and large scale, contrapuntal influences, cadential  progressions, non-chord tones.

MUS 5C.title: Theory of Western Art Music: Harmonic Practices and Analysis   II
MUS 5C.prereq_description: Placement exam. A grade of at least C- is required in each course of the
MUS 5C.description: Secondary dominants, diatonic modulation, chromatic chords, sequences.

MUS 6.title: Jazz Fundamentals
MUS 6.comments: Letter grade required for majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 8 units, but only 2 units may be applied towards the major.
MUS 6.description: Introduction to jazz harmony, scales, and improvization. drill in ear training and beginning keyboard.

MUS 8.title: Class Composition
MUS 8.comments: Primarily for the music major. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 18 units.
MUS 8.description: Assignments in basics of music writing.
MUS 8.recommended_prep: Basic ability to read and notate music.

MUS 10A.title: History of Western Music from Early Modern Culture through   Modernism
MUS 10A.description: A survey of Western music and its social contexts from late humanism through the Age of Enlightenment (1545-1745). Topics include Renaissance legacies, music and religious reformations, ancient vs. modern, the rise of opera, patronage, instrumental composer-performers, taste in the Enlightenment.

MUS 10B.title: History of Western Music from Early Modern Culture through   Modernism
MUS 10B.description: A survey of Western music and its social contexts from 1745 to 1848. Topics include the rise of public concerts and of the virtuoso soloist, the evolution of the orchestra, music in salons and parlors, and national operatic institutions.

MUS 10C.title: History of Western Music from Early Modern Culture through   Modernism
MUS 10C.description: A survey of Western music and its social contexts from 1848 to 1945. Topics include music and nationalism, late romanticism and the limits of tonality, modernism, the impact of popular music on art music, and neoclassicism.

MUS 11.title: Fundamentals of Music
MUS 11.description: The study of notes, scales, triads, inversions, rhythm, harmony, and musical terminology. Laboratory activities include keyboard orientation, sight singing, and ear training.

MUS 15.title: Music Appreciation
MUS 15.description: A selective survey of music of western civilization; evolution of forms, styles, media. Designed to enable the student to listen with understanding.

MUS 16.title: Listening to Jazz: Demystifying America's Musical Art Form
MUS 16.comments: Open to non-majors. Not open for credit to students who have completed Music 191 in spring 2018.
MUS 16.description: Aims to unravel the mystery of Jazz's allure, importance,  and performance process, in a manner mostly divorced from  technical musical terminology or music theory, through targeted readings, listening assignments, written projects, in-class visits, and concert attendance.

MUS 17.title: World Music
MUS 17.comments: No previous training in music required.
MUS 17.description: An introductory course surveying the unity and diversity of folk, traditional, and classical music of the non-western world. Emphasis given to dance, theatre, musical instruments, and the role of music in society.

MUS 17H.title: World Music, Honors
MUS 17H.comments: Students must have a cumulative 3.5 for the proceeding 1 quarter(s). Open to non-majors. Concurrently offered with Music 17. Quarters usually offered:Fall.
MUS 17H.description: Undergraduate independent research for honor students. Carefully selected topics in World Music intended to foster excellence in research or performance.

MUS 20A.title: Elementary Voice I
MUS 20A.prereq_description: Music 11 or UCSB Exam 38 (Music Theory Placement Test) with a score of 1 or higher. Placement by audition on the first day of class.
MUS 20A.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Primarily for the BA Music Major, the BM Instrumental Music Major and the Music Minor.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated 8 times for credit in combination with Music 20B and 20C toa maximum of 9 units, but only 6 units may be applied toward the major.
MUS 20A.description: Elementary voice lessons at beginning level. Placement in Music A, B, or C will be determined by the instructor after an audition.

MUS 20B.title: Elementary Voice II
MUS 20B.prereq_description: Music 11. Placement by audition the first day of class.
MUS 20B.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Primarily for the BA Music Major, the BM Instrumental Music Major and the Music Minor.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated 8 times for credit in combination with Music 20A and 20C toa maximum of 9 units, but only 6 units may be applied toward the major.
MUS 20B.description: Elementary voice lessons designed for those with a small amount of vocal experience.

MUS 20C.title: Elementary Voice III
MUS 20C.prereq_description: Music 11. Placement by audition on first day of class.
MUS 20C.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Primarily for the BA Music Major, the BM Instrumental Music major and the Music Minor.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated 8 times for credit in combination with Music 20A and 20B toa maximum of 9 units, but only 6 units may be applied toward the major.
MUS 20C.description: Elementary voice lessons designed for those who have significant vocal training and experience.

MUS 22AAZZ.title: Practicum in World Music Performance
MUS 22AAZZ.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. If there is no meeting time listed on the course schedule, contact instructor during first week of quarter to schedule instruction.
MUS 22AAZZ.description: Applied instruction in non-Western instruments: the Middle Eastern oud (lute) and nay (end-blown flute), Middle Eastern percussion, and dastgah (Persian melodic practice).

MUS 22D.title: Practicum in World Music Performance: Dastgah

MUS 22M.title: Practicum in World Music Performance: Arabic Maqam

MUS 22N. Practicum in World Music Perfor.number: 22N. Practicum in World Music Performance: the nay (Middle-  Eastern flute)

MUS 22O. Practicum in World Music Perfor.number: 22O. Practicum in World Music Performance: the oud (Middle-  Eastern lute)

MUS 22P.title: Practicum in World Music Performance: Middle Eastern   percussion

MUS 22V.title: Practicum in World Music Performance: the Middle Eastern   violin

MUS 24.title: Carillon
MUS 24.comments:
Open to non-majors. Concurrently offered with MUS 124. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Piano audition required. Contact instructor over email to schedule audition.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 9 units, but only 3 units may beapplied toward the major.
MUS 24.description: Applied instruction on Carillon (bells in bell tower) performance.
MUS 24.recommended_prep: Some keyboard proficiency (Music 31F, 32, or 33 or equivalent)   recommended.

MUS 25.title: Intermediate Voice
MUS 25.prereq_description: By audition. Departmental approval required prior to registration. Consent of instructor to finalize registration.
MUS 25.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Primarily for Music majors. Taken for 3 units per quarter by BM Voice emphasis majors and for 1-2 units per quarter by all others.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 9 quarters.

MUS 26A.title: Intermediate Double Bass
MUS 26A.prereq_description: By audition. Consent of instructor and department.
MUS 26A.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 27 units. Taken for 3 unit per quarter by BM Double Bass emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 26B.prereq_description: By audition. Consent of instructor and department.
MUS 26B.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 27 units. Taken for 3 units per quarter by BM Cello emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 26D.prereq_description: By audition. Consent of instructor and department.
MUS 26D.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 27 units. Taken for 3 units per quarter by BM Viola emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 26E.prereq_description: By audition. Consent of instructor and department.
MUS 26E.comments: May be repeated for credit to a amximum of 27 units. Taken for 3 units per quarter by BM Violin emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter for allothers.

MUS 27A.prereq_description: By audition. Consent of instructor and department.

MUS 29.title: Intermediate Percussion

MUS 29.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 27 units. Taken for 3 units per quarter by BM Percussion emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 31A.title: Class Piano
MUS 31A.prereq_description: Placement by audition. Must be taken consecutively. A grade of at least C- is
MUS 31A.description: Basic keyboard skills, major scales and chords, introduction to harmonization, easy piano repertoire.

MUS 31B.title: Class Piano
MUS 31B.prereq_description: Placement by audition. Must be taken consecutively. A grade of at least C-
MUS 31B.description: White key minor scales (natural/harmonic) and chords, harmonization, introduction to transposition and basic score reading, piano duets.

MUS 31C.title: Class Piano
MUS 31C.prereq_description: Placement by audition. Must be taken consecutively. A grade of at least C-
MUS 31C.description: Black key minor scales (natural/harmonic) and chords. Preparing for the proficiency exam: review of all scales and chords, more advanced harmonization, transposition. Learning a solo piece from the list of the appropriate repertoire.

MUS 31X.title: Class Piano
MUS 31X.prereq_description: Placement by audition; Music 31F with a minimum grade of C- or passing the piano proficiency test.
MUS 31X.comments: Primarily for Music Majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
MUS 31X.description: Optional continuation of Music 31. Equivalent in level to Music 32. Elementary individual class piano instruction in class or individual context. Includes scales, sight reading, transposition, harmonization at the keyboard, with emphasis on piano literature.

MUS 32A.title: Secondary Piano
MUS 32A.comments: Primarily for Music Majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
MUS 32A.description: Optional continuation of Music 31. Elementary individual class piano instruction. Includes scales, sight reading, transposition, harmonization at the keyboard, with emphasis on piano literature.

MUS 32B.title: Secondary Piano
MUS 32B.comments: Primarily for Music Majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
MUS 32B.description: Optional continuation of Music 31. Elementary individual class piano instruction. Includes scales, sight reading, transposition, harmonization at the keyboard, with emphasis on piano literature.

MUS 32C.title: Secondary Piano
MUS 32C.comments: Primarily for Music Majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
MUS 32C.description: Optional continuation of Music 31. Elementary individual class piano instruction. Includes scales, sight reading, transposition, harmonization at the keyboard, with emphasis on piano literature.

MUS 32D.title: Secondary Piano
MUS 32D.comments: Primarily for Music Majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
MUS 32D.description: Optional continuation of Music 31. Elementary individual class piano instruction. Includes scales, sight reading, transposition, harmonization at the keyboard, with emphasis on piano literature.

MUS 32E.title: Secondary Piano
MUS 32E.comments: Primarily for Music Majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
MUS 32E.description: Optional continuation of Music 31. Elementary individual class piano instruction. Includes scales, sight reading, transposition, harmonization at the keyboard, with emphasis on piano literature.

MUS 32F.title: Secondary Piano
MUS 32F.comments: Primarily for Music Majors. May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
MUS 32F.description: Optional continuation of Music 31. Elementary individual class piano instruction. Includes scales, sight reading, transposition, harmonization at the keyboard, with emphasis on piano literature.

MUS 33.title: Intermediate Piano
MUS 33.prereq_description: By audition. Consent of instructor and department.
MUS 33.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 27 units. Taken for 3 units per quarter by BM Piano emphasis and BM Piano Accompanying emphasis majors, andfor 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 35A.title: Piano Accompanying
MUS 35A.prereq_description: Music 33 (may be taken concurrently); or, Piano and Accompanying emphasis majors only; and, consent of instructor.
MUS 35A.description: An introduction to the study of accompaniment repertoire and performance (art song, instrumental literature, orchestral transcriptions, sight-reading).

MUS 35B.title: Piano Accompanying
MUS 35B.prereq_description: Music 33 (may be taken concurrently); or, piano and accompanying emphasis majors only; and, consent of instructor.
MUS 35B.description: An introduction to the study of accompaniment repertoire and performance (art song, instrumental literature, orchestral transcriptions, sight-reading).

MUS 35C.title: Piano Accompanying
MUS 35C.prereq_description: Music 33 (may be taken concurrently); or, Piano and Accompanying emphasis majors only; and, consent of instructor.
MUS 35C.description: An introduction to the study of accompaniment repertoire and performance (art song, instrumental literature, orchestral transcriptions, sight-reading).

MUS 35D.title: Piano Accompanying
MUS 35D.prereq_description: Music 33 (may be taken concurrently); or, Piano and Accompanying emphasis majors only; and, consent of instructor.
MUS 35D.description: An introduction to the study of accompaniment repertoire and performance (art song, instrumental literature, orchestral transcriptions, sight-reading).

MUS 51.title: Vocal and Instrumental Coaching
MUS 51.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated to a maximum of 9 units, but only 3 units may be applied toward the major.
MUS 51.description: Musical preparation of vocal or instrumental works from a coach/accompanist.

MUS 52.title: Vocal & Instrument Coaching Supervision
MUS 52.description: Music preparation of vocal or instrumental works from a coach/accompanist. Coaches and accompanists are assigned by a faculty member.

MUS 53.title: Viola Orchestral Repertoire
MUS 53.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
MUS 53.description: The study of the entire standard orchestral repertoire for viola and audition procedures.

MUS 54.title: Acting for Singers
MUS 54.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
Repeat Comments: Majors can only repeat once for credit.
MUS 54.description: Study of techniques and practice of acting on the stage for singers as preparation for performing operatic roles, in lecture and workshop settings.

MUS 88.title: Intermediate Composition
MUS 88.prereq_description: Passing of freshman composition portfolio and consent of instructor.
MUS 88.comments:
Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. For selected students.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units but only 6 units may beapplied toward the major.

MUS 97.title: Sophomore Audition
MUS 97.prereq_description: Passing of freshman audition (may be waived for transfer students) and consent of instructor.
MUS 97.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.

MUS 98.title: Readings in Music
MUS 98.comments: Students must have a 3.0 minimum GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined. May be repeated for credit to 6 units.
MUS 98.description: Critical review and discussion of related topics in musicology, ethnomusicology, composition, theory, or performance.

MUS 99.title: Introduction to Musical Research
MUS 99.comments: Students must have a 3.0 minimum GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined. May be repeated for credit to 6 units.
MUS 99.description: Independent research under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Course offers exceptional students the opportunity to undertake independent research or work in a research group in topics in musicology, ethnomusicology, composition, theory, or performance.

MUS 101A.title: Contemporary Techniques
MUS 101A.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
MUS 101A.description: A study of contemporary techniques, through both written work and analysis.

MUS 101B.title: Contemporary Techniques
MUS 101B.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
MUS 101B.description: A study of contemporary techniques, through both written work and analysis.

MUS 101C.title: Contemporary Techniques
MUS 101C.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
MUS 101C.description: A study of contemporary techniques, through both written work and analysis.

MUS 102.title: Fundamentals of Counterpoint
MUS 102.description: A study of the general principles of counterpoint based on literature and repertoire of various periods, complemented by written exercises.

MUS 103.title: Eighteenth Century Counterpoint
MUS 103.description: A study of contrapuntal practices of the eighteenth century through analysis and compositional exercises.

MUS 105.title: Field and Laboratory Methods in Ethnomusicology
MUS 105.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring. Because Music 176 is the prerequisite and is usually taught in the fall, Music 105 can be taught in either winter or spring.
MUS 105.description: The development and execution of field research designs. Practical field experience using various techniques of data collection and management including music recording, photography, filming, questionnaires, and interviewing. The use and interpretation of standard and innovative laboratory methods for processing data, including computer analysis.

MUS 106A.title: Orchestration
MUS 106A.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
MUS 106A.description: The study of orchestration through written work and analysis.

MUS 106B.title: Orchestration
MUS 106B.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
MUS 106B.description: The study of orchestration through written work and analysis.

MUS 106C.title: Orchestration
MUS 106C.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
MUS 106C.description: The study of orchestration through written work and analysis.

MUS 108.title: Advanced Composition
MUS 108.prereq_description: Music 5C or equivalent, passing of sophomore composition portfolio and
MUS 108.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 3 units per quarter by BM Composition emphasis majors and for 1-2 units per quarterby all others.
MUS 108.description: Individual instruction in composition. Assignments using small and large forms.

MUS 109CA.title: Introduction to Interactive Audio
MUS 109CA.description: An introductory course in interactive music technology. Through technical instruction, critical reflection, and original work in Max, a visual programming environment, students investigate the influence of personal computing, digital media, and interactivity on electronic music and sonic art.

MUS 109IA.title: Direct Digital Synthesis, Processing and Composition
MUS 109IA.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
MUS 109IA.description: First quarter of general purpose computing for computer music applications. Topics include: introduction to the UNIX operating system and the VI editor, music synthesis using C-music program and score input programs.

MUS 109IB.title: Direct Digital Synthesis, Processing and Composition
MUS 109IB.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
MUS 109IB.description: Series concentrating on computer instrument design using C-  based computer music software and exploring synthesis applications of frequency modulation, amplitude modulation, additive/substractive synthesis, etc., computer processing of sound, and computer music composition.

MUS 109L.title: Real-Time Digital Synthesis, Processing, and Composition
MUS 109L.comments: Quarters usually offered: Fall. Required for Composition majors. Other music majors and non-majors may enroll on a space available basis.
MUS 109L.description: An introductory course on electroacoustic music. Historical perspective. Analysis of different types of electronic/acousmatic/mixed compositions. Introduction to different techniques of sound transformation.

MUS 109LA.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated once with permission of instructor, but used only once for credit in the major (2 units).
MUS 109LA.description: First quarter of a 3-quarter series course in real-time digital synthesis and composition will concentrate on multi-  track recording, mixing, digital signal processing using micro-computers and special purpose DSP equipment for music composition.

MUS 109LB.title: Real-Time Digital Synthesis, Processing and Composition
MUS 109LB.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated once with permission of instructor, but used only once for credit in the major (2 units).
MUS 109LB.description: Second quarter of a 3-quarter series course will concentrate on digital synthesis (primarily frequency modulation, simple and complex; but also amplitude modulation and additive synthesis) using micro-computers, digital synthesizers and processing equipment for music composition.

MUS 109LC.title: Real-Time Digital Synthesis, Processing and Composition
MUS 109LC.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated once with permission of instructor, but used only once for credit in the major (2 units).
MUS 109LC.description: Third quarter of a 3-quarter series course will concentrate on real-time computer music composition with micro-computers and digital synthesis/processing equipment.

MUS 109N.title: Special Topics in Computer Music and Digital Signal Processing
MUS 109N.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
MUS 109N.description: Advanced topics in computer music composition, synthesis and digital signal processing.

MUS 109TA.title: Introduction to Visual Music
MUS 109TA.prereq_description: MUS 109IA; or, MUS 109LA; or, consent of instructor.
MUS 109TA.comments: Designed for majors. Non majors may enroll with consent of instructor.
MUS 109TA.description: Introductory course on Visual Music. Historical perspective. Intro to Final Cut Pro, After Effects, Cinema 4D and other visual music composition software. Several short exercises will be required.

MUS 113A.description: An overview of the history of opera from 1600-1800, placing selected works within a social context, and viewing opera as a musical work, dramatic spectacle, and cultural commodity.

MUS 113B.description: An overview of the history of opera from 1800-1960, placing selected works within a social context, and viewing opera as a musical work, dramatic spectacle, and cultural commodity.

MUS 114.title: Music and Popular Culture in America
MUS 114.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Summer, Fall.
MUS 114.description: A survey of the relationships between music and popular culture in America. Music to be discussed includes blues, jazz, and rock, as well as classical music. Emphasis is on cultural, rather than technical aspects of music.

MUS 115.title: Symphonic Music
MUS 115.prereq_description: Music 15 or Music 3A. Music 3A may be taken concurrently.
MUS 115.comments: Open to non-majors. Contact departmental advisor for an approval code if concurrently enrolled in Music 3A.
MUS 115.description: A study of selected symphonic works.

MUS 116.title: American Music History: From the Colonial Period to the   Present
MUS 116.description: An overview of the varieties of American musical experience from the Colonial period to the present. Representative works from several genres are studies with a view to placing them in their cultural context and identifying major aesthetic issues.

MUS 117.title: Music and the Mind
MUS 117.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
MUS 117.description: Introduction to the psychology of music. Topics include music perception and cognition, learning and memory, emotion and meaning, music and language, music and the brain, emergence and development of skills, perspectives from social and cultural psychology, well-being and therapy, and others.

MUS 118A.title: History and Literature of Great Composers in Western Music
MUS 118A.description: A survey of the life and stylistic development of the music of an individual composer selected from the fourteenth to the twentieth century. A) Ludwig van Beethoven; B) J.S. Bach; C) Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart; D) Frederic Chopin; E) Joseph Haydn; F-Z) other composers.

MUS 119A.title: Music and Politics
MUS 119A.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Summer. Primarily for non-majors but also open to majors.
MUS 119A.description: A study of the interaction between music and politics from the fourteenth century to the present. Includes discussion of relevant art from each period.

MUS 119B.title: Music in Political Films
MUS 119B.description: Survey of some of the major films in the political film genre (1916-2007) in addition to readings on the political/ historical topic. Will learn basic terminology and techniques of analysis for film music.

MUS 120A.title: Orchestral Conducting
MUS 120A.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units, but only 4 units may be applied toward the major.
MUS 120A.description: An introduction to fundamentals of orchestral conducting and score reading.

MUS 120B.title: Choral Conducting
MUS 120B.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units, but only 4 units may be applied toward the major.
MUS 120B.description: An introduction to the fundamentals of choral conducting and score reading.

MUS 120C.title: Advanced Conducting
MUS 120C.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units, but only 2 units may beapplied toward the major.
MUS 120C.description: Applied instruction in choral or orchestral conducting.

MUS 120T.title: Choral Techniques
MUS 120T.prereq_description: Music 120B (may be taken concurrently) and consent of instructor.
MUS 120T.description: Aspects of choral techniques; including: development of concert programs and rehearsal plans, rehearsal procedures, types of vocal ensembles and seating configurations, acoustical considerations, performance and recording procedures, long-term programming and artistic development, social and organizational aspects of vocal ensemble.

MUS 122AAZZ.title: Practicum in World Music Performance
MUS 122AAZZ.comments: Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. If there is no meeting time listed on the course schedule, contact instructor during first week of quarter to schedule instruction.
MUS 122AAZZ.description: Applied instruction in non-Western instruments: the Middle Eastern oud (lute) nay (end-blown flute), Middle Eastern percussion, and dastgah (Persian melodic modes).

MUS 124.title: Advanced Carillon
MUS 124.prereq_description: Consent of instructor. At least 3 quarters of Music 24.
MUS 124.comments:
Open to non-majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Piano audition required. Contact instructor over email to schedule audition.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 9 units, but only 6 units may beapplied toward the major.
MUS 124.description: Applied instruction on Carillon (bells in bell tower) performance.
MUS 124.recommended_prep: Some keyboard proficiency (Music 31F, 32, or 33 or equivalent)   recommended.

MUS 125.title: Advanced Voice
MUS 125.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 3 units per quarter by BM Voice emphasis majors and for 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 126B.title: Advanced Cello
MUS 126B.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 4 units per quarter by BM Cello emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 126D.title: Advanced Viola
MUS 126D.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 4 units perquarter by BM Viola emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 126E.title: Advanced Violin
MUS 126E.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 4 units perquarter by BM Violin emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 127A.title: Advanced Bassoon
MUS 127A.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 4 units per quarter by BM Bassoon emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter by allothers.

MUS 127B.title: Advanced Clarinet
MUS 127B.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 4 units per quarter by BM Clarinet emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 127C.title: Advanced Flute
MUS 127C.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 4 units per quarter by BM Flute emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 127D.title: Advanced Oboe
MUS 127D.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 4 units perquarter by BM Oboe emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 128A.title: Advanced French Horn
MUS 128A.prereq_description: Passing of french horn sophomore audition.
MUS 128A.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 4 units perquarter by BM French Horn emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 128B.title: Advanced Trombone
MUS 128B.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 4 units perquarter by BM Trombone emphasis majors, and 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 128C.title: Advanced Trumpet
MUS 128C.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 4 units perquarter by BM Trumpet emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter by allothers.

MUS 128D.title: Advanced Tuba
MUS 128D.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 4 units perquarter by BM Tuba emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units per quarter by all others.

MUS 129.title: Advanced Percussion
MUS 129.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 4 units perquarter by BM Percussion emphasis majors, and for 1 unit per quarter by allothers.

MUS 133.title: Advanced Piano
MUS 133.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 36 units. Taken for 4 units perquarter by BM Piano emphasis majors, and for 1-2 units by all others.

MUS 135A.title: Piano Accompanying
MUS 135A.prereq_description: Music 33 (may be taken concurrently); or, Piano and Accompanying emphasis majors only; and, consent of instructor.
MUS 135A.description: An advanced study of accompaniment repertoire and performance (artsong, instrumental literature, orchestral transcriptions, sight-reading).

MUS 135B.title: Piano Accompanying
MUS 135B.prereq_description: Music 33 (may be taken concurrently); or, Piano and Accompanying emphasis majors only; and, consent of instructor.
MUS 135B.description: An advanced study of accompaniment repertoire and performance (artsong, instrumental literature, orchestral transcriptions, sight-reading).

MUS 135C.title: Piano Accompanying
MUS 135C.prereq_description: Music 33 (may be taken concurrently); or, Piano and Accompanying emphasis majors only; and, consent of instructor.
MUS 135C.description: An advanced study of accompaniment repertoire and performance (artsong, instrumental literature, orchestral transcriptions, sight-reading).

MUS 135D.title: Piano Accompanying
MUS 135D.prereq_description: Music 33 (may be taken concurrently); or, Piano and Accompanying emphasis majors only; and, consent of instructor.
MUS 135D.description: An advanced study for accompaniment repertoire and performance (artsong, instrumental literature, orchestral transcriptions, sight-reading).

MUS 135E.title: Piano Accompanying
MUS 135E.prereq_description: Music 33 (may be taken concurrently); or, Piano and Accompanying emphasis majors only; and, consent of instructor.
MUS 135E.description: An advanced study for accompaniment repertoire and performance (artsong, instrumental literature, orchestral transcriptions, sight-reading).

MUS 135F.title: Piano Accompanying
MUS 135F.prereq_description: Music 33 (may be taken concurrently); or, Piano and Accompanying emphasis majors only; and, consent of instructor.
MUS 135F.description: An advanced study for accompaniment repertoire and performance (artsong, instrumental literature, orchestral transcriptions, sight-reading).

MUS 150.title: Opera/Song Repertoire
MUS 150.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 12 units. Letter grade required for majors.
MUS 150.description: A detailed study of operatic literature and concert literature (lieder, melodies, songs, and pieces with instruments). The interpretation of vocal music as a preparation for performance.

MUS 151.title: Vocal and Instrumental Coaching
MUS 151.prereq_description: Concurrent upper-division vocal or instrumental study (Music 125-129).
MUS 151.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for a maximum of 9 units, but only 3 units may be applied toward the major.
MUS 151.description: Musical preparation of vocal or instrumental works.

MUS 152.title: Vocal & Instrument Coaching Supervision
MUS 152.description: Music preparation of vocal or instrumental works from a coach/accompanist. Coaches and accompanists are assigned by a faculty member.

MUS 153.title: Viola Orchestral Repertoire
MUS 153.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit up to 9 units.
MUS 153.description: The study of the entire standard orchestral repertoire for viola, and audition procedures.

MUS 154.title: Acting for Singers
MUS 154.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
Repeat Comments: Majors can only repeat once for credit.
MUS 154.description: Study of techniques and practice of acting on the stage for singers as preparation for performing operatic roles, in lecture and workshop settings.

MUS 158D.title: Diction
MUS 158D.prereq_description: Primarily for Voice majors. Music 25 or equivalent.

MUS 160A.title: Tonal Analysis
MUS 160A.prereq_description: Music 4C; Music 5C with a grade of at least C-.
MUS 160A.description: Analysis of small- and large-scale formal structures in music from the late Baroque through the late Classic period (ca. 1720-1820).

MUS 160B.title: Twentieth Century Analysis
MUS 160B.prereq_description: Music 4C; Music 5C with a grade of at least C-.
MUS 160B.description: Analysis of non-tonal and twelve-tone music.

MUS 160C.title: Advanced Tonal Analysis
MUS 160C.description: Continuation of Music 160A, advanced tonal analysis through nineteenth century works.

MUS 160D.title: Tuning and Temperament
MUS 160D.description: Survey of a number of tuning systems found around the world, including those of Ancient Greece, Europe, India, China, the Arab Middle East, Turkey, and Indonesia. The mathematical, aesthetic, and symbolic bases of each system will be considered.

MUS 160E.title: The Arabic System of Melodic Modes: The Maqamat
MUS 160E.description: An intensive examination of the system of melodic modes (Maqamat) that governs present-day practice in the eastern Arab world. Emphasis given to theoretical issues (quarter tones, tetrachordel structures, and theories of intonation), analysis of standard repertoire, and procedures governing improvisation.

MUS 160F.title: Sound Color: Timbre and Music
MUS 160F.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
MUS 160F.description: "Sound color" refers to the quality or timbre of musical sound, whether instrumental, vocal, or synthetic. This course investigates timbre's special perceptual and cognitive qualities, as well as its unique expressive power in music.

MUS 161.title: Keyboard Literature
MUS 161.prereq_description: Music 11 or Music 5A; Music 10A, or Music 10B, or Music 10C  OR WITH CONSENT OF INSTRUCTOR.
MUS 161.description: A comprehensive survey of the history and development of stringed keyboard instruments and the repertoire associated with these diverse instruments. An extensive listening list will be available via the Naxos Music Library.

MUS 162.title: Choral Literature
MUS 162.prereq_description: Three quarters of the Music 112A-F series.
MUS 162.description: A historical and analytical survey of major choral works from the seventeenth century to the present.

MUS 168A.title: Popular Music & Globalization
MUS 168A.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
MUS 168A.description: Through the interface of globalization and music, we will explore the cultural  politics of nation and person, community and commodity, in modern societies, as well as the ways recording and  broadcasts of music have changed musical practices and experiences.

MUS 168C.title: Music and Religion
MUS 168C.comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed Music 166A.
MUS 168C.description: An examination of the structural role and symbolic functions of music in religious systems. Case studies will be drawn from diverse world traditions.

MUS 168G.title: Other Issues in Ethnomusicology
MUS 168G.comments:
Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated three times as long as subject matter is different.
MUS 168G.description: A study of other cultural issues in ethnomusicology. Specific issue or topics will vary by quarter and will be announced in advance by the department.

MUS 168H.title: Music and Tourism
MUS 168H.description: Students read folklore, anthropology, tourism studies, musicology, and ethnomusicology in an attempt to develop theories for interpreting the impact of tourism on music locally and globally.

MUS 168I.title: Film Music Cognition
MUS 168I.prereq_description: Music 11 or Music 5A (which may be concurrent); and upper-division standing.
MUS 168I.description: A consideration of film music as a medium of communication between the director, composer, music supervisor, editors, performers and the audience. Emphasis given to cognitive psychological theories of meaning in terms of structure and affect in audio/visual contexts.
MUS 168I.recommended_prep: Upper-division standing or consent of the instructor.

MUS 168J.title: Music and Documentary Film
MUS 168J.description: View global popular music through the lens of documentary film. We will analyze a series of films depicting cultural and political histories, creative performances, and everyday lives of musicians in different representational frames and social contexts.

MUS 168M.title: Music as Media
MUS 168M.comments: Open to non-majors. Concurrently offered with Music 262M.
MUS 168M.description: Recorded media are central to the way we hear, create, exchange and experience music in contemporary social life. Topics include the early uses of the phonograph, recording studios, file-sharing, online musical exchange and roles of technological media in globalizing cultures.

MUS 168P.title: Creative Arts, Memories and Experimental Performance
MUS 168P.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
MUS 168P.description: Through creative arts practices, analysis, workshops and new performance, this course explores processes of transformation and translation of traces of memories and experiences into provocative art works. Experimental performance practices encompass theatrical, movement based, sonic, music-based and visual arts.

MUS 168R.title: History and Practice of the Recording Studio
MUS 168R.description: Explores contemporary histories and techniques of the recording studio, focusing on the role of sound engineers in US/UK postwar popular music. In addition to exploring the history of recorded sound, the class will provide students with opportunities to learn practical methods of music production.

MUS 168S.title: Music and Sports
MUS 168S.description: In this course, students study connections between the human cultural practices of music and sport. We draw from rich literatures in performance studies, sports studies, and ethnomusicology to consider selected case studies where music and sport intersect.

MUS 168T.title: Birds, sonic arts & environmental sensitivities
MUS 168T.comments:
Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
Repeat Comments: Repeat of MUS168G with Hellier-Tinoco in Spring 2021.
MUS 168T.description: Focusing on birds and sonic arts, this course engages creative, analytical & experiential activities. Topics include: ecoacoustics, sound maps, deep listening, sensory memory, soundscape ecologies and environmental issues, blurring borders between more-than-human/human interactions, art/science, and local/global.

MUS 168X.title: Umm Kulthum: Her Music, Her Life, Her Times
MUS 168X.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors.
MUS 168X.description: Analysis of the music, life, an times of the predominant Arab singer of the twentieth century. Individual projects may focus on music or text analysis, issues of gender, nationalism, agency, performance practice, and investigation of related arts (film, novels, etc.).

MUS 174.title: Musical Acoustics
MUS 174.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; Music 11 or Music 5A (which may be concurrent).
MUS 174.comments: Lower division students can enroll with consent of instructor.
MUS 174.description: Consideration of the relationships between acoustics, perception and music. Emphasis on the physical and psychophysiological bases for tonality, dynamics, timbre and rhythm. Additional focus on the vibrational properties of musical instruments and features of digital recording and playback.

MUS 175F.title: Music Cultures of the World: The Middle East
MUS 175F.description: Arab, Turkish, and Persian music traditions from historical, cultural, and musicological perspectives. Emphasis given to the position of music in Islam, present-day performers, and modal and rhythmic structures.

MUS 175G.title: Music Cultures of the World: India
MUS 175G.description: A survey of music traditions of the Indian subcontinent from classical to folk and popular. Emphasis on the position of music in Hindu philosophy, the role of music in society, musical instruments, and modal and rhythmic structures (Raga and Tala).

MUS 175I.title: Music Cultures of the World: Indonesia
MUS 175I.comments: Open to non-majors. Concurrently offered with 293I.
MUS 175I.description: Introduces Indonesian musical and cultural practices through folk, classical, popular musics; religious traditions, theater and dance. Topics include interconnection of sonic and social structures, historical conditions of colonial and postcolonial relationships with the West, and transitions to contemporary transnational circulations.

MUS 175J.title: Music in Modern Japan
MUS 175J.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Concurrently offered with MUS 293J. Quarters usually offered: Fall.
MUS 175J.description: This course explores music and culture in modern Japan. What kind of society do we hear in its diverse mix of sounds and musical practices? We explore this question through traditional genres, national politics, and transnational exchanges of popular media.

MUS 175K.title: Music Cultures of the World: Other Regions
MUS 175K.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units.
MUS 175K.description: A study of music traditions and genres from other regions of the world. Specific regions studied vary by quarter and are announced in advance by the department.

MUS 175L.title: Music Culture of the Polish Tatra Mountains
MUS 175L.description: The Tatras are the home of a distinct folk culture, including music based on polyphonic singing ad violin ensembles. Course investigates the present-day music from this region and its history, and examines the influence of tourism and ethnography on the music-culture.

MUS 175M.title: American Folk Music: Old-Time, Bluegrass and Country
MUS 175M.description: Study of English-language American folk music, using mixed-media tools for learning. The focus is on string band music often associated with Appalachia and usually called "old-time," and the distinct but related styles of bluegrass and country.

MUS 175P.title: Eco-Acoustic-Arts: Sounding & Creating with Global Environmental Elements
MUS 175P.prereq_description: Upper division standing, instructor approval required.
MUS 175P.description: In eco-acoustic-arts, students investigate & create with geo and bio elements (including water, plants, rocks, animals).  Using sounding as an inspirational process to explore ecological entanglements (scientific, cultural, artistic), methods include sensory ethnography, ethography, mapping & digital technologies.

MUS 175W.title: Music, Community, Wellbeing: Advocacy and Activism
MUS 175W.description: Taking a vocational and facilitatory approach, this course uses case studies to explore concepts and processes of generating and sustaining musical activity as community-engaged practice. Topics include: social justice, health and wellbeing, education, senses of place, ecology, and technology.

MUS 175X.title: Musics in Mexico
MUS 175X.comments: Open to non-majors. Concurrently offered with MUS 293X. Quarters usually offered: Spring.

MUS 176.title: Studies in Ethnomusicology
MUS 176.description: An introduction to the field of ethnomusicology using theories and methods derived from the social sciences and humanities. Topic areas to include transcription and analysis, musicians, musical instruments, music acculturation, and the function of music in society.

MUS 181.title: Proseminar in Baroque Music
MUS 181.comments:
Course designed for majors.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units as long as subject matter is different.
MUS 181.description: A selective study of various stylistic and historical aspects of Baroque music.

MUS 182.title: Proseminar in Classical Music
MUS 182.comments:
Course designed for majors.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units as long as subject matter is different.
MUS 182.description: A selective study of various stylistic and historical aspects of classical music.

MUS 183.title: Proseminar in Romantic Music
MUS 183.comments:
Course designed for music majors.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units as long as subject matter is different.
MUS 183.description: A selective study of various stylistic and historical aspects of romantic music.

MUS 184.title: Proseminar in Contemporary Music
MUS 184.comments:
Designed for majors. Course designed for majors
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units as long as subject matter is different.
MUS 184.description: A selective study of various stylistic and historical aspects of contemporary music.

MUS 188.title: Ethnomusicology Forum
MUS 188.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
Repeat Comments: Music 188 may be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units.
MUS 188.description: A forum for the presentation of research and performance by students, faculty, and visiting scholars and performers.

MUS 191.title: Special Topics
MUS 191.prereq_description: Upper-division standing and consent of instructor.
MUS 191.description: Special seminar in selected problems of current musicology, ethnomusicology, theory, or performance.

MUS 192.title: B.A. Senior Project
MUS 192.prereq_description: Open to B. A. senior Music majors only.
MUS 192.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
MUS 192.description: Preparation of senior audition, composition, or paper.

MUS 192A.title: B.A. Senior Project
MUS 192A.prereq_description: Open to B.A. senior Music Studies majors only.
MUS 192A.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
Repeat Comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed MUSIC 192.
MUS 192A.description: The first quarter of preparation of senior audition, composition, or paper.

MUS 192B.title: B.A. Senior Project
MUS 192B.prereq_description: Music 192A with a minimum grade of C-.
MUS 192B.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Open to B.A. senior Music Studies majors only.
Repeat Comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed MUSIC 192.
MUS 192B.description: The second quarter of preparation of senior audition, composition, or paper.

MUS 192C.title: B.A. Senior Project
MUS 192C.prereq_description: Music 192B with a minimum grade of C-.
MUS 192C.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Open to B.A. senior Music Studies majors only.
Repeat Comments: Not open for credit to students who have completed MUSIC 192.
MUS 192C.description: The third and final quarter of preparation of senior audition, composition, or paper.

MUS 195.title: Junior Recital
MUS 195.prereq_description: Passing of B.M. sophomore audition; open to upper-division Bachelor of Music Performance Emphasis major only.

MUS 196.title: Honors Music
MUS 196.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; honors students only; consent of instructor and department.
MUS 196.comments:
Students must have a cumulative 3.5 for the proceeding 6 quarter(s). Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. For Distinction in the Major must be taken with Music 192 or 197 or 197B.
Repeat Comments: Music 196 is available not only in conjunction with Music 192, 197, and 197B for Departmental Senior Honors (Distinction in the Major), but can also be taken separately for other Honors projects by students in the College of Letters and Science Honors program.
MUS 196.description: An undergraduate independent research for honor students. Carefully selected topics intended to foster excellence in research, theory, composition, or performance.

MUS 197.title: Senior Recital
MUS 197.prereq_description: Passing of junior recital; open to senior Music Performance emphasis majors only.

MUS 197B.title: Senior Composition Portfolio and Recital
MUS 197B.prereq_description: Passing of junior composition portfolio; and, consent of instructor; open tsenior BM Composition emphasis majors only.

MUS 199.title: Individual Research in Music
MUS 199.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of three quarters of the Music 112AB-F series; consent of instructor.
MUS 199.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined. Students are limited to 4 units per quarter and 16 units total in Music 198/199 courses.
MUS 199.description: Independent research under the guidance of a faculty member in the department. Course offers qualified students the opportunity to undertake independent research or work in a research group in topics in musicology, ethnomusicology, composition, theory, or performance.

MUS 199RA.title: Independent Research Assistance in Music
MUS 199RA.prereq_description: Upper-division standing; completion of three quarters of the Music 112AB-F series; consent of instructor and department.
MUS 199RA.comments: Students must have a minimum 3.0 GPA for the preceding 3 quarters and are limited to 5 units per quarter and 30 units total in all 98/99/198/199/199AA-ZZ courses combined. Students are limited to 4 units per quarter and 16 units total in Music 198/199 courses. No more than 4 units in combination with Music 199 may be applied to major.

MUS 200A.title: Bibliography and Research Techniques
MUS 200A.comments: Primarily intended for the MM and DMA graduate student in Music.
MUS 200A.description: A survey of music bibliography and research methods.

MUS 200B.title: Bibliography and Research Techniques
MUS 200B.comments: Primarily intended for the M.A. and Ph.D. graduate student in musicology ortheory.
MUS 200B.description: Survey and discussion of select historical, methodological, and theoretical approaches to research in musicology.

MUS 200D.title: Bibliography and Research Techniques
MUS 200D.comments: Primarily for the M.A. and Ph.D. graduate student in theory.
MUS 200D.description: A survey of music bibliography and research methods in theory.

MUS 202A.title: Seminar in Musicology
MUS 202A.prereq_description: M.A. or equivalent with consent of instructor. For advanced students only.
MUS 202A.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. A two-quarter in-progress sequence course with grades for both quarters.
MUS 202A.description: May be repeated for credit. Seminar in musicology. First quarter of a two-quarter doctoral seminar dealing with selected topics in musicology.

MUS 202B.prereq_description: M.A. or equivalent with consent of instructor. For advanced students only.
MUS 202B.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring. A two-quarter in-progress sequence course with grades for both quarters issued.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit.
MUS 202B.description: Taken upon completion of Music 202A. Seminar in musicology. Second quarter of a two-quarter doctoral seminar dealing with selected topics in musicology.

MUS 203MT.title: Musicology-Theory Forum
MUS 203MT.prereq_description: Graduate standing in musicology or theory emphasis.
MUS 203MT.description: Theory students, faculty and visiting scholars present their current research.

MUS 204A.title: Graduate Musicianship I
MUS 204A.description: An introduction for graduate students who fail the musicianship placement exam. 204A reviews diatonic ear-training skills and their relation to theory. All graduate students encouraged to enroll; theory/ composition students should especially consider 204 as a pedagogical study.

MUS 204B.title: Graduate Musicianship II
MUS 204B.description: Continues skills of 204A; reviews musicianship skills for modulation. All graduate students encouraged to enroll; theory/ composision students shouldespecially consider 204B as a pedagogical study of musicianship.

MUS 204C.title: Graduate Musicianship III
MUS 204C.comments: All graduate students welcome; theory and composition students especially encouraged to take 204C as a pedagogical study.
MUS 204C.description: Continue skills of Music 204A and B; reviews musicianship skills for chromatic harmony.

MUS 208.title: Graduate Composition
MUS 208.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Required for M.A. and Ph.D. in composition.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit.

MUS 209IA.title: Direct Digital Synthesis, Processing and Composition
MUS 209IA.comments: Graduate music majors and graduate non-majors in areas of electrical engineering, computer science, physics, and mathematics.
MUS 209IA.description: First quarter of general purpose computing for computer music applications. Topics include: introduction to the UNIX operating system and the vi editor, music synthesis using C-based computer programs and score input programs.

MUS 209IB.title: Direct Digital Synthesis, Processing and Composition
MUS 209IB.description: Second quarter of a three-quarter sequence will concentrate on computer music instrument design using C-based music software and exploring applications of frequency modulation, amplitude modulation, additive/subtractive synthesis, digital signal processing and computer music composition.

MUS 209L.title: Introduction to Electroacoustic Music
MUS 209L.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Required for Composition majors. Music majors and non-majors may also enroll.
MUS 209L.description: An introductory course on electroacoustic music. Historical perspective. Analysis of different types of electronic/acousmatic/mixed compositions. Introduction to different techniques of sound transformation.

MUS 209LA.title: Real-Time Digital Music Synthesis, Processing and Composition
MUS 209LA.prereq_description: Consent of instructor. Graduate music majors and graduate non-majors in areas of electrical engineering, computer science, physics, and mathematics.
MUS 209LA.description: First quarter of a three-quarter sequence course will concentrate on multi-track recording, mixing, digital signal processing using micro-computers and special purpose dsp equipment.

MUS 209LB.title: Real-Time Digital Music Synthesis, Processing and Composition
MUS 209LB.description: Second quarter of a three-quarter sequence course will concentrate on digital synthesis (primarily frequency modulation, simple and complex; but also amplitude modulation and additive synthesis) using micro-computers, digital synthesizers and processing equipment.

MUS 209LC.title: Real-Time Digital Music Synthesis, Processing and Composition
MUS 209LC.description: Third quarter of a three-quarter sequence course will concentrate on real-time computer music composition with micro-computer and digital synthesis/processing equipment.

MUS 209N.title: Special Topics in Electronic Music
MUS 209N.description: Advanced topics in computer music composition, synthesis, and digital signal processing.

MUS 209TA.title: Introduction to Visual Music
MUS 209TA.prereq_description: Mus 211B or Mus 109IA or Mus 209IA or Mus 109LA or Mus 209LA or consent of instructor.
MUS 209TA.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Designed essentially for majors. Non-majors may also enroll with the consent of the instructor.
MUS 209TA.description: Introductory course on Visual Music. Historical perspective. Introduction to Final Cut Pro, After Effects, Cinema 4D and other visual music composition software.  Several short exercises will be required during the quarter.

MUS 209TB.title: Visual Music Composition
MUS 209TB.prereq_description: MUS 209TA or consent of the instructor
MUS 209TB.comments: Designed essentially for majors. Non-majors may also enroll with the consent of the instructor. May be repeated with permission of instructor but usedonly once for credit in major.
MUS 209TB.description: Visual Music composition. Mixing, synthesis, animation, sound-image integration. An original Visual Music composition is required after the end of the course.

MUS 210A.title: Software Development as a Means to Composition
MUS 210A.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
MUS 210A.description: First quarter of a course devoted to composition by means of software. Existing software of this nature will be demonstrated, discussed and where possible, used by students to generate compositions.

MUS 210B.title: Theory and Analysis of Electroacoustic Music
MUS 210B.prereq_description: Mus 209L or Mus 209IA or Mus 209LA or consent of the instructor
MUS 210B.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated 2 additional times after initial offering, but only 4.0 units may be applied toward the major.
MUS 210B.description: Discussion of selected readings in the field. Analysis of compositions. A short analysis or aesthetics paper is required after the end of the course.

MUS 211A.title: Contemporary Composition Techniques (Instrumental)
MUS 211A.prereq_description: Passing grade on all theory placement examinations.
MUS 211A.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Fall. Designed/required for Composition majors.
MUS 211A.description: Study of different compositional techniques based on the analysis of pieces from the repertoire. Rhythm manipulation, harmonic contents, formal aspects, integration between instruments and electronics, extended techniques, gesture control, etc. A short paper explaining the application of one or more of these techniques in an original composition is required after the end of the course.

MUS 211B.title: Contemporary Composition Techniques (Electroacoustic)
MUS 211B.prereq_description: Mus 209L or Mus 209IA or Mus 209LA or consent of the instructor
MUS 211B.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter.
Repeat Comments: Designed/required for Composition majors. Music majors and non-majors may also enroll with the consent of the instructor. Usually taught in Winter quarter. May be repeated with permission of instructor but used only once formajor credit.
MUS 211B.description: Study of different compositional techniques based on sound objects transformations. Analysis of pieces from the repertoire. Synthesis, recording, mixing, sound object transformation techniques, spatialization. An original 5-8 min acousmatic/electronic music composition is required after the end of the course.

MUS 211C.title: Contemporary Composition Techniques (Electroacoustic and Mixed Music)
MUS 211C.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring. Designed for Composition majors. Usually taught in Spring quarter. May be repeated with permission of instructor but used only once for major credit.
MUS 211C.description: Composition class in electroacoustic music (acousmatic/electronic/mixed). An original 5-8 min acousmatic/electronic/mixed music composition is required after the end of the course.

MUS 211D.title: Special Topics in Composition
MUS 211D.comments: Designed for Composition majors. Music majors and non-majors may also enroll with the consent of instructor.
MUS 211D.description: Advanced topics in classical or contemporary composition techniques or aesthetics.

MUS 212A.title: Advanced Counterpoint
MUS 212A.comments: Designed essentially for Composition and Theory students who did not pass the counterpoint diagnostic exam. Credits do not count towards the degree. Other Music major students can take it for credit.
MUS 212A.description: Study of 16th or 18th century counterpoint. Compositional exercises required during the quarter.

MUS 212B.title: Advanced Harmony
MUS 212B.comments: Designed essentially for Composition and Theory students who did not pass the harmony diagnostic exam. Credits do not count towards the degree. Other Music major students can take it for credit.
MUS 212B.description: Study of chorale, elaborated chorale, lied and other harmonization techniques. Compositional exercises required during the quarter.

MUS 212C.title: Canon and Fugue
MUS 212C.prereq_description: Passing grade on all theory placement guidance examinations.
MUS 212C.description: A detailed study of Bach's canons and fugues, including invertible counterpoint, stretto, triple and quadruple counterpoint, as well as extensions by later and contemporary composers. Extensive compositional exercises required.

MUS 219.title: Applied Instruction
MUS 219.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Not for the performance emphasis in MM or DMA degree programs.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit.
MUS 219.description: Applied vocal or instrumental instruction for graduate students other than in the performance emphasis discipline of MM and DMA degree programs.

MUS 220.title: MM/DMA Performance Instruction
MUS 220.prereq_description: Entrance audition for MM or DMA degree program.
MUS 220.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Restricted to MM and DMA majors admitted to the performance emphasis in voice or the specific instrument of study in Music 220.
MUS 220.description: Applied instruction in the performance emphasis discipline (MM piano accompanying: instruction in piano) of MM and DMA degree programs.

MUS 222AAZZ.title: Practicum in World Music Performance
MUS 222AAZZ.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Graduate standing.
MUS 222AAZZ.description: Individual or group instruction in non-Western instruments: the Indian sitar, the Middle Eastern `ud (lute) and nay (end-blown flute), and Middle Eastern percussion.

MUS 222X.title: Practicum in World Music Performance
MUS 222X.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall. Graduate standing.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit.
MUS 222X.description: Individual or group instruction in non-Western instruments: the Indian sitar, the Middle Eastern `ud (lute) and nay (end-blown flute), and Middle Eastern percussion.

MUS 224.title: Organology
MUS 224.description: A systematic study of musical instruments in world cuiltures involving classification, distribution, acoustical phenomena, and physical typo- groupings, and the role of musical instruments in the study of acculturation, historical diffusion, and aesthetics.

MUS 225.title: Field and Laboratory Methods in Ethnomusicology
MUS 225.description: The development and execution of field research designs. Practical field experience using various techniques of data collection and management, including music recording, photography, filming, questionaires, and interviewing. The use and interpretation of standard and innovative laboratory methods for processing data, including computer analysis.

MUS 227.title: Seminar in Ethnomusicology
MUS 227.description: A graduate seminar examining special problems, current theories, analytic procedures, and recent innovations in ethnomusicology.

MUS 230.title: Orchestral Conducting
MUS 230.comments: Enrollment by audition. May be repeated for credit.
MUS 230.description: Advanced conducting techniques, score reading and analysis, general rehearsal procedures and repertoire for each type of ensemble: symphony, chamber orchestra and large vocal/instrumental ensembles.

MUS 231.title: Choral Conducting
MUS 231.comments: Enrollment by audition. May be repeated for credit.
MUS 231.description: Advanced conducting techniques, score reading and analysis, rehearsal techniques and repertoire for vocal and choral ensembles.

MUS 231T.title: Choral Techniques
MUS 231T.prereq_description: Music 231 (may be taken concurrently) and consent of instructor.
MUS 231T.description: Aspects of choral techniques, including: development of concert programs and rehearsal plans, rehearsal procedures, types of vocal ensembles and seating configurations, acoustical considerations, performance and recording procedures, long-term programming and artistic development, social and organization aspects of vocal ensemble.

MUS 233A.title: Score Reading
MUS 233A.comments: Required for MM and DMA degrees in conducting. May be repeated for credit.
MUS 233A.description: A practical survey of score-reading of selected orchestral scores of the eighteenth, nineteenth, and twentieth centuries including a detailed study of the necessary transcriptions and their relationship to the various clefs.

MUS 235A.title: Accompanying Techniques and Repertoire
MUS 235A.description: Emphasizes advanced accompaniment techniques, the intensive study of the French and German song cycle, secco recitative, and orchestral score-reading.

MUS 235B.title: Accompanying Techniques and Repertoire
MUS 235B.description: Emphasizes advanced accompaniment techniques, the intensive study of the French and German song cycle, secco recitative, and orchestral score-reading.

MUS 235C.title: Accompanying Techniques and Repertoire
MUS 235C.description: Emphasizes advanced accompaniment techniques, the intensive study of the French and German song cycle, secco recitative, and orchestral score-reading.

MUS 250A.title: Seminar in Music Theory
MUS 250A.description: Analysis and theory of atonal music.

MUS 250B.title: Seminar in Music Theory
MUS 250B.description: Analysis and theory of twelve-tone music.

MUS 251A.title: Seminar in the History of Theory

MUS 251B.title: Seminar in the History of Theory
MUS 251B.description: History of music theory from Rameau to Schenker.

MUS 252A.title: Seminar in Schenkerian Analysis
MUS 252A.prereq_description: Must be taken in consecutive order.
MUS 252A.description: Readings in the theory of Schenkerian analysis. Basic analytical techniques.

MUS 252B.title: Seminar in Schenkerian Analysis
MUS 252B.prereq_description: Must be taken in consecutive order.
MUS 252B.description: Advanced readings in Schenkerian theory. Analysis of large forms.

MUS 253.title: Viola Orchestral Repertoire
MUS 253.comments:
Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring, Fall.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for up to 36 units.
MUS 253.description: The study of the entire standard orchestral repertoire for viola and audition procedures.

MUS 254.title: Acting for Singers
MUS 254.comments:
Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
Repeat Comments: Course can be repeated unlimited number of times. Only 6 units can be counted towards credit in the major.
MUS 254.description: Study of techniques and practice of acting on the stage for singers as preparation for performing operatic roles, in lecture and workshop settings.

MUS 256.title: Vocal and Instrumental Coaching
MUS 256.prereq_description: Concurrent graduate vocal or instrumental study (Music 220, 219, 235) graduate standing; consent of instructor.
MUS 256.description: Musical preparation of vocal or instrumental works.

MUS 257.title: Composition Forum
MUS 257.comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 6 units toward major.
MUS 257.description: A forum for the presentation and discussion of new works by students, faculty, and guest composers.

MUS 258.title: Opera/Song Repertoire
MUS 258.description: A detailed study of operatic literature and concert literature (Lieder, melodies, songs, and pieces with instruments). The interpretation of vocal music as a preparation for performance.

MUS 259.title: Keyboard Literature
MUS 259.description: A study of the history and literature of keyboard music from the baroque through the twentieth century.

MUS 260A.title: Music Cognition
MUS 260A.description: Surveys research in music cognition and introduces empirical methods for studying music. Topics include music perception and cognition, memory and expectation, emotion and meaning, emergence and development of skills and performance, perspectives from social and cultural psychology, among others.

MUS 260D.title: Tuning and Temperament
MUS 260D.description: The course surveys a number of tuning systems around the world, including those of ancient Greece, Europe, India, China, the Arab Middle East, Turkey, and Indonesia. The mathematical, aesthetic, and symbolic basis of each system will be considered.

MUS 260E.title: The Arab System of Melodic Modes (Maqamat)
MUS 260E.description: Examination of the system of melodic modes (maqamat) governing present-day melodic practice in the eastern Arab world. Emphasis given to theoretical issues (quarter tones, tetrachordal structures, theories of intonation), analysis of pieces in the repertoire, and procedures governing improvisation.

MUS 260F.title: Sound Color
MUS 260F.description: "Sound color" refers to the quality or timbre of musical sound, whether instrumental, vocal, or synthetic. This course investigates timbre's special perceptual and cognitive qualities, as well as its unique expressive power in music.

MUS 260G.title: Tonal Analysis Review
MUS 260G.description: An in-depth review of elements and procedures of 18th- and 19th-century harmony, aimed at analyzing conventional formal types (binary, ternary, rondo, sonata, sonata-rondo, concerto).

MUS 262G.title: Other Issues in Ethnomusicology
MUS 262G.comments:
Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
Repeat Comments: May be repeated for credit to a maximum of 16 units, provided topics are different.
MUS 262G.description: A study of other cultural issues in ethnomusicology. Specific topics vary by quarter and will be announced in advanced by the department.

MUS 262H.title: Music and Tourism
MUS 262H.description: Students read folklore, anthropology, tourism studies, musicology, and ethnomusicology in an attempt to develop theories for interpreting the impact of tourism on music locally and globally.

MUS 262I.title: Film Music Cognition
MUS 262I.description: A consideration of film music as a medium of communication between the director, composer, music supervisor, editors, performers and the audience. Emphasis given to cognitive psychological theories of meaning in terms of structure and affect in audio/visual contexts. Students are required to propose and complete an experiment in film music cognition.

MUS 262M.title: Music as Media
MUS 262M.description: Recorded media are central to the way we hear, create, exchange and experience music in contemporary social life. Topics include the early uses of the phonograph, recording studios, file-sharing, online musical exchange and roles of technological media in globalizing cultures.

MUS 262Q.title: Performance Studies
MUS 262Q.comments: Open to non-majors. Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Spring.
MUS 262Q.description: An exploration of the contemporary field of performance studies, relevant for students in all areas of music study. Inherently interdisciplinary, subjects encompass production, reception, technologies, embodiment, politics, geographies, identities, and virtualities.

MUS 262X.description: Analysis of the music, life and times of the predominant Arab singer of the twentieth century. Individual projects may focus on music or text analysis, issues of gender, nationalism, agency, performance, practice and investigation of related arts (film, novels, etc.).

MUS 266.title: Seminar in Musicology: The Classical Period
MUS 266.description: Graduate seminar in music of the classical period.

MUS 267.title: Seminar in Musicology
MUS 267.comments: Designed for majors. Quarters usually offered: Winter, Spring, Fall.
MUS 267.description: Graduate Seminar in Musicology. Topics will vary.

MUS 268.title: Seminar in Musicology: The Romantic Period
MUS 268.description: Graduate seminar in music of the Romantic period.

MUS 269.title: Seminar in Musicology: The Twentieth Century
MUS 269.description: Graduate seminar in music of the twentieth century.

MUS 274.title: Musical Acoustics
MUS 274.comments:
Final Project for Graduate Students in lieu of Final Exam.
Repeat Comments: No Repeats.
